1.1 Version control
Version control allows to control any changes done to a code. There are different types of version control systems, but the most useful ones are the distributed ones.

title: 1  Git and Github
text:
1.2 Git
What is Git:

It is an free and open-source software distributed under the GNU license.
It is a distributed version control system (DVCS): this means that any user can have a copy of a project, make changes locally and then sync changes with the main remote project.

What does it do: - It supports branching strategy.
Brackground: was developed in 2005 to satisfy Linux needs of version-control.

text:

title: 1  Git and Github
text:
1.4 Important terms to learn

SSH (secure shell) protocol: method to secure remote login.
Repository: contains the project folders that are set uo for version control.
Fork: copy of a repository
Pull request: is a request to someone to review and approve your changes before they become final.
Working directory: contains files associated to a git repository
Commit: a snapshot of the current state of a project
Branch: is a separate line of development that allows you to work independently on your changes.
Merging: combines changes from one branch to another.
Cloning: creates a local copy of a remote git repository

title: 3  Git branches
text:
3.2 Other branches
When you plan to change the code:

Create a new branch:


Command line: in the local repository of interest (previously you have changed to the local repository using cd and make sure that the local repository is a git repository which means that you have used git init in the directory of interest), use git checkout -b "name of branch". This new branch is a exact copy of the original branch.
Github: in the repository of interest, go to tab “master”, and fill in the space that indicates “Find or create a branch”



Work on the new branch. Once the new code is finished, we have two branches: the original and the copy.
When both branches are ready to join, the code of each branch is called the tip of each branch.
Merge the branches: the two tips of the branch are merged into a new tip that belongs to the original branch that contains the deployable branch.

 # Git Branching Workflow

Clone the repository git clone URL
Create branch git branch BRANCH_NAME
Switch to the new branch using git checkout BRANCH_NAME
Modify the targeted file
Check modifications using git status
Stage changes using git add FILE_NAME
Commit changes using git commit -m "Message"
Switch back to the main branch using git checkout main
Merge branches using git merge
Make the changes accessible to the remote repository using git push -u origin main
Check if changes have been done using git status

text:
14.2 Several branches

14.2.1 Option 1: You first updated the main brannch using the workflow as the repository had only the main branch, and then you realize there are more branches

14.2.1.1 The other branch is contained in the main branch

List all branches git branch -a
Check the commits that the other branches have and that main does not have git log --oneline --graph main..otherbranch If you do not get any output, then it means that the other branch does not have any commit that it not in the main branch.
Check the commits that main has and the other bramches do not have git log --online --graph otherbranch..main
Confirm the differences between main and other branches git diff -stat main..otherbranch
git diff -stat otherbranch..main
The differences are shown because we compare the files between different commits.
Now, let’s verify the last common commit between main and the other branch
git merge-base main otherbranch
Now, let’s verify the tip of the other branch
git rev-parse otherbranch

If they are equal, the other branch is fully contained into the main one and it can be safey deleted.

Delete the branch git branch -d otherbranch
Push the changes = delete remotely git push origin --delete otherbranch
